Glycogen is a complex polymer of glucose molecules involved in the storage of energy in many organisms. Depending on the signals received by a cell, different enzymes are activated, which will lead to either the synthesis or breakdown of glycogen. The product of glycogen breakdown, glucose <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>phosphate, can be modified into glucose <math alttext="6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>6-</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>phosphate, an intermediate of glycolysis (Figure 1).

Figure 1. Glycogen synthesis and breakdown

In the liver, glycogen synthase and glycogen phosphorylase are regulated by kinases. These kinases transfer phosphate groups from <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to amino acids in glycogen synthase and glycogen phosphorylase. Phosphorylase kinase <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="P K B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PKB</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) is a kinase that regulates glycogen synthase kinase <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="G S K 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GSK3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) activity. <math alttext="G S K 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GSK3 </mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> regulates the activity of glycogen synthase. Phosphorylase kinase (<math alttext="P K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>PK</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) regulates the activity of glycogen phosphorylase. The activity of these kinases depends on the activation of signaling pathways in response to the binding of specific cell signals, including insulin and glucagon, to their receptors (Figure 2).

Figure 2. A simplified model of signaling pathways in a liver cell that are activated by insulin and glucagon

(a) A cell has a mutation that disrupts the insulin binding site of the insulin receptor. Based on the information in Figure 2, predict the effect of this mutation on the activity of <math alttext="G S K 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GSK3</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your prediction.
